meanings.definition: A group or set of twenty.
meanings.sent1: The teacher divided the students into a scorse for the group activity.
meanings.sent2: There were a scorse of apples in the basket.
meanings.sent3: The scorse of colorful balloons made the party decorations pop.
meanings.sent4: The scorse of birds flying in formation was a mesmerizing sight.
meanings.sent5: Counting by scorse made it easier to keep track of the items.

meanings.sent1: She decided to scorse the cake into equal slices for the party.
meanings.sent2: The chef needed to scorse the ingredients carefully for the recipe.
meanings.sent3: He tried to scorse his time between work and hobbies but found it challenging.
meanings.sent4: The river seemed to scorse the landscape in a natural and beautiful way.
meanings.sent5: The artist planned to scorse the canvas into sections for different paintings.

meanings.sent1: The team's scorse at the end of the game determined the winner.
meanings.sent2: She kept a scorse of her savings in a notebook.
meanings.sent3: The scorse of goals achieved motivated him to work harder.
meanings.sent4: The scorse of votes cast showed a clear winner in the election.
meanings.sent5: The scorse of points on the board indicated a close match between the teams.
